content.question: A person touches a metal cart with rubber wheels that moves along a carpeted surface. The person feels a shock. Which of the following claims is correct and provides correct justification?

choices.label: The shock did not come from the wheels because they are made of rubber, which is an insulator, they cannot be charged by friction with the floor.
The shock did not come from the wheels, because the charges that were created when the wheels rolled along the floor, were destroyed upon contact with the person.
The person could have experienced a shock whether the cart had an excess positive or negative charge because in either case an excess charge will be neutralized when given a path to the ground.
The person could have experienced a shock whether the cart had an excess positive or negative charge because in either case the charge is destroyed upon contact with the person.

content.answer: The person could have experienced a shock whether the cart had an excess positive or negative charge because in either case an excess charge will be neutralized when given a path to the ground.

topic.text: 10.2: Conservation of Electric Charge and the Process of Charging

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
